repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
Currently, `vim.snippet.expand` automatically creates mappings for `tab` and `shift-tab`. This is done as part of our efforts to provide some default keybindings. However, silently overriding users' existing tab and shift-tab mappings is not a good approach, especially since this is not even documented. There are too many customization possibilities with mappings. The default behavior should inject mappings only when they don't already exist, rather than overwriting them. I have checked #30306 and previous discussions, but I still believe that overriding users' mappings can cause confusion.

Solution:
Add mapping checks to ensure that mappings are injected only if they do not already exist.

comment_regular_data.body: This does not address all the problems brought up in the linked issue. I don't think simply slapping such a check in solves the problem. A proper fix should enable customization to cover all (reasonable) use cases.
This does not solve that issue. I have stated the intent.  question is why silently overwrite the existing user mapping?

> I have checked https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/30306 and previous discussions,

 i think i already checked https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/30198 linked in that issue. but i don't feel like explains the behavior of forcibly overwriting the user mapping. Providing defaults is good. But don't override the user's settings. It makes no sense.

To allow -- for now, until we have proper official integration -- coexistence with other snippet plugins. I'm not saying that this is not an issue that need not be solved; I'm saying that this is not the correct solution for it.
again PR is not created to solve that issue. Instead, is it possible to check if the user is already mapped? ? please read commit message carefully..

I have read it, and that exact issue has been discussed in the linked (closed) issue: There are situations where it's _desired_ to temporarily(!) override an existing mapping in the snippet context. The correct solution is to make that behavior opt-in/out, not remove it entirely.

> There are situations where it's desired to temporarily(!) override an existing mapping

Do you mean this includes breaking the default tab on insert behavior? In the case of indentation that requires a tab, it will jump to the snippet. obviously, this is unreasonable. default tab is changed by this override.??!

Of course not. Any snippet "tab" mapping will check for a valid placeholder first and fall back to literal `<tab>` otherwise. This is unrelated to whether you set it by default or not.

Again, I am in favor of making it configurable, but not of simply removing it.

Not quite. For example, `namespace $1 { \n $0 }` The second tab to $0 I continue tabbing it will just jump to $1 because $1 is still valid what i expect there should be tab an indnet not jump. You can't check like this. First of all, it shouldn't be circular. Second, it shouldn't override any expected user behavior. Because I can handle this situation myself.
That sounds like a bug that should be fixed; reaching `$0` should exit the snippet.

$0 is the last one section which defined in lsp spec. But this behavior is completely configurable by the user. But why override it? And no we have no documentation to mark this. I can't understand overriding this behavior. This infringes on the user's space.

repo.name: neovim

title: fix(snippet): don't auto map tab and s-tab when already have define
